sen.j: 安寧天皇（あんねいてんのう、綏靖天皇5年（紀元前577年）- 安寧天皇38年12月6日 (旧暦)（紀元前510年1月17日））は、『古事記』『日本書紀』に伝えられる第3代の天皇（在位：綏靖天皇33年7月3日 (旧暦)（紀元前549年8月31日） - 安寧天皇38年12月6日 (旧暦)（紀元前510年1月17日））。
sen.e: Emperor Annei (A.D.577-January 11, 510) is the third Emperor, who was described in "Kojiki"(The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki"(Chronicles of Japan) (Reign: August 13, A.D.549-January, 11,510).

Emperor Annei (577 B.C.- January 11, 510 B.C.) is the third emperor, who was described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) (Reign: August 13, 549 B.C. -January 11, 510 B.C.).
sen.cmt: 紀元前はB.C.なので記述をA.DからB.C.に変更。
sen.e: Emperor Annei (577 B.C.- January 11, 510 B.C.) is the third emperor, who was described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) (Reign: August 13, 549 B.C. -January 11, 510 B.C.).

sen.j: 磯城津彦玉手看尊（しきつひこたまてみのみこと）・師木津日子玉手見命（『古事記』）。
sen.e: In "kojiki", he is called Shikitsuhikotamatemi no mikoto or Shikitsuhikotamademi no mikoto.
In kojiki, he is called Shikitsuhikotamatemi no mikoto or Shikitsuhikotamademi no mikoto.
sen.cmt: Kojikiは既出なので引用符を削除
sen.e: In kojiki, he is called Shikitsuhikotamatemi no mikoto or Shikitsuhikotamademi no mikoto.

sen.j: いわゆる欠史八代の1人で、実在しない天皇と捉える見方が一般的である。
sen.e: He was one of the so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns), and it is commonly understood that he was the nonexistent Emperor.
He is one of the so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns), and it is commonly understood that he was a nonexistent Emperor.
He is one of the so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns), and it is commonly understood that he was a nonexistent Emperor.

sen.j: （実在説もある）
sen.e: (There is also the theory of his real existence).
(There is also the theory of his existence).
(There is also the theory of his existence).

sen.j: 片塩浮孔宮（かたしおのうきあなのみや）。
sen.e: Imperial Palace was Katashio no ukiana no miya.
Imperial Palace was Katashio no ukiana no miya.
Imperial Palace was Katashio no ukiana no miya.

sen.j: 『古事記』にも「片塩浮穴宮」。
sen.e: In "Kojiki", there is a description that the Imperial Palace was "Katashio no ukiana no miya."
In Kojiki, there is a description that the Imperial Palace was "Katashio no ukiana no miya."
sen.cmt: Kojikiは既出なので引用符を削除
sen.e: In Kojiki, there is a description that the Imperial Palace was "Katashio no ukiana no miya."

sen.j: 所在地については、以下の3説がある。
sen.e: There are three theories concerning the location of the Palace as follows.
There are three theories concerning the location of the Palace as follows.
There are three theories concerning the location of the Palace as follows.

sen.j: 奈良県橿原市四条町付近 （『帝王編年記』『和州旧跡幽考』）
sen.e: Area around Shijo Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture ("Teio Hen-nenki", "Washu kyuseki yuko")
Area around Shijo Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture ("Teio Hen-nenki", "Washu kyuseki yuko")
Area around Shijo Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture ("Teio Hen-nenki", "Washu kyuseki yuko")

sen.j: 奈良県大和高田市三倉堂・片塩町 （『大和志』『古都略紀図』）
sen.e: Mikurado・Katashio cho, Yamatotakada City, Nara Prefecture ("Yamatoshi", "kotoryakukizu")
Mikurado・Katashio cho, Yamatotakada City, Nara Prefecture ("Yamatoshi", "kotoryakukizu")
Mikurado and Katashio cho, Yamatotakada City, Nara Prefecture ("Yamatoshi", "kotoryakukizu")
sen.cmt: 中黒を削除、地図で確認してandで結びました。

sen.j: 大阪府柏原市内 （『古事記伝』『大日本地名辞書』）
sen.e: Kashiwabara City, Osaka Prefecture ("Kojiki-den" (Commentary on the Kojiki), "Dai Nihon Chimei Jisho" (Encyclopedia for place names of Great Japan))
Kashiwabara City, Osaka Prefecture ("Kojiki-den" (Commentary on the Kojiki), "Dai Nihon Chimei Jisho" (Encyclopedia for place names of Great Japan))
Kashiwabara City, Osaka Prefecture ("Kojiki-den" (Commentary on the Kojiki), "Dai Nihon Chimei Jisho" (Encyclopedia for place names of Great Japan))

sen.j: 前後の諸宮が全て奈良盆地の中に位置しているので、候補としては第1・2説が有力とみられるが、その詳細は不明である。
sen.e: As all his former and later palaces were located in Nara Basin, the first and second theories are considered to be most convincing as possible location, but the details are unknown.
In Kojiki, there is a description that the Imperial Palace was "Katashio no ukiana no miya."
In Kojiki, there is a description that the Imperial Palace was "Katashio no ukiana no miya."

sen.j: なお、大和高田市に存する「片塩」「浮孔」の町名・施設名（例：浮孔駅）は全て、第2説に基づいた近代以降の復古地名に過ぎない。
sen.e: Name of towns and facilities (e.g. Ukina Station) such as "Katashio" and "Ukina" existing in Yamatotakada City are all just Fukko chimei (returning to old name of places) after the early modern times, which were based on the second theory.
sen.cmt: 復古地名の定訳が不明です。
sen.e: Names of towns and facilities (e.g. Ukina Station) such as "Katashio" and "Ukina" currently existing in Yamatotakada City are all just Fukko chimei (returning to an old name of the place) after the early modern times, based on the second theory.
sen.cmt: Name を複数形に変更、その他一部表現の見直し
sen.e: Names of towns and facilities (e.g. Ukina Station) such as "Katashio" and "Ukina" currently existing in Yamatotakada City are all just Fukko chimei (returning to an old name of the place) after the early modern times, based on the second theory.

sen.j: 事績
sen.e: Achievements
Achievements
Achievements

sen.j: 特に記録されていない。
sen.e: There is no particular description about his achievements.
There is no particular description about his achievements.
There is no particular description about his achievements.

sen.j: 綏靖天皇25年正月（紀元前557年）に立太子、同33年（紀元前549年）父天皇の崩御を受けて、7月に即位。
sen.e: In A.D. 557, he was formally installed as Crown Prince, then he ascended the throne in August, A.D.549 after the death of his father in the same year.
In 557 B.C., he was formally installed as Crown Prince, then he ascended the throne in August, 549 B.C. after the death of his father in the same year.
In 557 B.C., he was formally installed as Crown Prince, then he ascended the throne in August, 549 B.C. after the death of his father in the same year.

sen.j: 在位38年で崩御。
sen.e: He died in the 38th year of his reign.
He died in the 38th year of his reign.
He died in the 38th year of his reign.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』に57歳（67歳？）、『古事記』に49歳という。
sen.e: According to "Nihon shoki", he died at the age of 57 (67?), while according to "Kojiki", he died at the age of 49.
According to Nihon shoki, he died at the age of 57 (67?), while according to Kojiki, he died at the age of 49.
According to Nihon shoki, he died at the age of 57 (67?), while according to Kojiki, he died at the age of 49.

sen.j: 畝傍山西南御陰井上陵（うねびやまのひつじさるのみほとのいのえのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: Emperor Annei was buried in Unebiyama no hitsujisaru no mihoto no inoe no misasagi.
Emperor Annei was buried in Unebiyama no hitsujisaru no mihoto no inoe no misasagi.
Emperor Annei was buried in Unebiyama no hitsujisaru no mihoto no inoe no misasagi.

sen.j: 『古事記』に「畝傍山の美富登（みほと）」。
sen.e: In "Kojiki", there is a description that "his misasagi is located in Unebiyama no mihoto."
In Kojiki, there is a description that "his misasagi is located in Unebiyama no mihoto."
In Kojiki, there is a description that "his misasagi is located in Unebiyama no mihoto."

sen.j: 現在、同陵は奈良県橿原市吉田町に所在する俗称「アネイ山」（山形墳）に比定される。
sen.e: Currently, this misasagi is identified with the mountain shaped barrow popularly known as "Aneiyama", which is located in Yoshida cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Currently, this misasagi is identified with the mountain shaped barrow popularly known as "Aneiyama", which is located in Yoshida cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Currently, this misasagi is identified with the mountain shaped barrow popularly known as "Aneiyama", which is located in Yoshida cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 元禄修陵では所在を誤ったが、幕末修陵に際して現陵に治定。
sen.e: In Genrokushuryo (the restoration of the imperial tombs in the Genroku era of the Edo period), the location of Emperor Annei's misasagi was mistaken, but in Bakumatsushuryo (the restoration of the imperial tombs in the end of Edo period) the current site was authorized as his misasagi.

In Genrokushuryo (the restoration of the imperial tombs in the Genroku era of the Edo period), the location of Emperor Annei's misasagi was mistaken, but in Bakumatsushuryo (the restoration of the imperial tombs in the end of Edo period) the current site was authorized as his misasagi.

In Genrokushuryo (the restoration of the imperial tombs in the Genroku era of the Edo period), the location of Emperor Annei's misasagi was mistaken, but in Bakumatsushuryo (the restoration of the imperial tombs in the end of Edo period) the current site was authorized as his misasagi.

sen.j: 陵号の由来になったとされる古井戸の「御陰井」が陵南の集落中にあり、陵と共に宮内庁によって管理されている。
sen.e: The old well "mihotonoi", which is considered to be the origin of the title of this misasagi is located in the town of the south of misasagi,and that well is managed by the Imperial Household Agency with misasagi.

The old well "mihotonoi", which is considered to be the origin of the title of this misasagi, is located in the town of the south of misasagi,and that well is managed by the Imperial Household Agency with misasagi.
sen.cmt: is locatedの前にカンマを挿入
sen.e: The old well "mihotonoi", which is considered to be the origin of the title of this misasagi, is located in the town of the south of misasagi,and that well is managed by the Imperial Household Agency with misasagi.
